channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-16460] Can't rebuild the BucketAllocator's data structures when BucketCache uses FileIOEngine
item.description:
When bucket cache use FileIOEngine, it will rebuild the bucket allocator's data structures from a persisted map. So it should first read the map from persistence file then use the map to new a BucketAllocator. But now the code has wrong sequence in retrieveFromFile() method of BucketCache.java.


      BucketAllocator allocator = new BucketAllocator(cacheCapacity, bucketSizes, backingMap, realCacheSize);

      backingMap = (ConcurrentHashMap<BlockCacheKey, BucketEntry>) ois.readObject();
item.summary: Can't rebuild the BucketAllocator's data structures when BucketCache uses FileIOEngine

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Upload a patch to fix this.

+1 overall

+1. Good catch. 


public static class HFileBlockPair {

This can be marked with @visibileForTesting tag. Rest looks good to me.
Upload v1 patch. Add VisibleForTesting and delete cache file after unit test.
Good.. +1
+1. Can you prepare patches for the 0.98 and branch-1.x specifically? - am not sure if they apply cleanly there.

Wait a moment before commit.. So till now the persistence of cache was not getting effective even if we used persistent File for cache. Need to eval all implication down the line because of this change. So how was it previously before this fix? We will have the file already (cache file) and we will continue to use that. Overwrite the data there? So the issue was that when the RS restarts and the same Regions which was there in this RS comes back to this RS, still we have to read from HDFS to load the FIle cache. (The data might be there already)
There are things like below in the constructor


for (int i = 0; i < bucketSizes.length; ++i) {

        if (foundLen <= bucketSizes[i]) {

          bucketSizeIndex = i;

          break;

        }

      }

      if (bucketSizeIndex == -1) {

        throw new BucketAllocatorException(

            "Can't match bucket size for the block with size " + foundLen);

      }

This means over the restart of the RS the bucket sizes (which is configurable by users) should not get changed. If so there is a chance that we will not see a suitable bucket for a block and so we will fail this L2 cache init. We throw Exception!

So how was it previously before this fix?

Before this fix, the code in the constructor never be called because backing map is empty...

If so there is a chance that we will not see a suitable bucket for a block and so we will fail this L2 cache init. We throw Exception!

If it can't find a suitable bucket for a block, the block can't be catch before rs restart. So after rs restart, it can't throw exception if the user don't change the bucket sizes config.

I mean a config change in btw this restart. Just adding my thinking.. As this path was never used there because of this bug( I agree this is a very bag bug in our side), making sure the fix wont impact in any way.. Trying to make all view all angles .. So after all checks we can get this in.. U get my point right?

This means over the restart of the RS the bucket sizes (which is configurable by users) should not get changed. If so there is a chance that we will not see a suitable bucket for a block and so we will fail this L2 cache init. We throw Exception!

I think yes. But it seems to be valid correct? Otherwise there is no use of persistence?

Ok. I took a look about the previous code, it can cache block but can't read block from cache or read wrong data from cache when backing map is inconsistent with bucking allocator. After this fix, the backing map is also inconsistent with bucking allocator if we got exception...... Maybe we should remove the bucket entry from the backing map if we got exception?

+1 overall

Anoop Sam John
Good with the latest patch for commit?

for (Map.Entry<BlockCacheKey, BucketEntry> entry : map.entrySet()) {

Can we create an iterator over the map entryset and the failed ones just remove from iterator? No need for 2 loops. Also why to throw Exception in try and catch directly under. Just handle directly.
v3 patch. Add ut for reconfig bucket sizes.

Iterator<BlockCacheKey> iterator = map.keySet().iterator();

356	    while (iterator.hasNext()) {

357	      BlockCacheKey key = iterator.next();

358	      BucketEntry entry = map.get(key);

This is not efficient way. You can create an iterator over the entryset so that u can avoid map.get() call for every key. U will see a Findbugs issue for this.

Also rather than logging at many places and so possibly making more log lines, we can collect all such failed keys into a List and log them at once at the end (If the list size is >0)

Thanks for your review.

we can collect all such failed keys into a List and log them at once at the end

But we will miss the failed reason? Use a map to collect all failed keys and exceptions?
OK.. Leave my comment on this then pls.

-1 overall

Sorry did not see all the exception throw - Log warn deeply.


if (reconfigured[bucketNo]) {	

373	        if (b.sizeIndex() != bucketSizeIndex)		

374	          throw new BucketAllocatorException(		

375	              "Inconsistent allocation in bucket map;");		

376	      } else {	389	      } else {

377	        if (!b.isCompletelyFree())		

378	          throw new BucketAllocatorException("Reconfiguring bucket "		

379	              + bucketNo + " but it's already allocated; corrupt data");

These 2 instances are like safety checks. I feel we can keep the original exception throw way only here.. Only the first 2 instances where we try to get the bucket and a slot in that, we need to handle. It can happen, we may not a slot for a particular block (if the bucket sizes reconfigured in btw the restart). WDYT?

Or else am +1 for latest patch. (Just need avoid the code change in above 2 places)
Lets target this for 1.3+ versions. Can get into older active versions if RMs favoring to do.
Agree. We should throw these exception and if we got these exception, we should use a empty baking map. I will upload a new patch.
Upload v5 patch.

ramkrishna.s.vasudevan you will commit this right?

405	      LOG.warn("There are " + sizeNotMatchedCount + " blocks which can't rebuild because ",

406	        new BucketAllocatorException("Can't match bucket size for these blocks"));

Looks like the BucketAllocatorException wouldn't provide much information. Just append the second message to the first - that way we don't need BucketAllocatorException.
Same comment applies to the next warning log.
Yeah...The BucketAllocatorException can provide more stack trace?

When we see the log, it should have the line number (just for illustration):

2016-09-01 16:53:49,697 INFO [M:0;192.168.0.14:59181] flush.MasterFlushTableProcedureManager(78):

There is no need to include stack trace.

Patch v6 removes BucketAllocatorException in the two warnings.

Guanghao, is this Okay ?
Looks good to me. Thanks Ted. It is our Saturday, so I don't have time to fix it now......Thanks again.
